intro: Achillea glomerata, commonly known as yarrow, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Asteraceae family and is characterized by its dense clusters of small, white or pale yellow flowers. The plant has feathery, aromatic leaves and is often found in meadows, woodland edges, and rocky soils. It grows to a height of about 30–60 cm and blooms from late spring to early autumn. Achillea glomerata is known for its medicinal properties and has been used historically for its antiseptic and anti-inflammatory effects.
